content:
By elongation andithe acquisition of cilia, a planula is pro-
duced. It swims heavify but rolls and crawls actively on the bottom
like a planarian. httaehing hy its small hind end, it produces a
succession of tentacles, and actively sends out numerous anastomosing
encrusting hydrorhiza processes, from which sprout new individuals.
Observe specimens that have been growing several days or a week.
Remove several male reproductive individuals showing ripe
sporosacs, and crush them under a coverslip on a glass
slide. This may be done by drawing off some of the water with
blotting paper. The sporosacs fall far short of being perfect
medusae. Note stages in the production of sperm within them. Burst
a mature sporosac and study the sperm under high power.
Similarly crush several female reproductive individuals, and
observe the eggs with their large germinal vesicles, in various
stages of development. (Bunting 
Tubularia (June, July)
The gonosomes of a well~matured specimen form long racemes or
clusters of gonophores crowding and drooping from the region between
the two circles of tentacles on a hydranth. The gonophores are quite
severely reduced medusae which never become free-swimming, usually 
have no evident radial or circular canals and develop nothing but
buds for tentacles, Wits rare exceptions male and female gonophores
occur in separate colonies, male colonies being a very small minor-
ity. Diagnosis of se; by sight is impossible in the immature, but
gonophores that contain embryos are easy to poll from those that
are filled with a cloudy mass of sperm.
Examine a male gonophore, considering it as a very degenerate
medusa. Notice its mode of attachment, its shape, the structure of
its free end and the position of the sperm surrounding the dark rod
manubrium. Crush a ripe male gonophore on a slide and inspect the
motile sperm under high power.
Examine a female gonophore. Usually the tentacles at its distal
ond appear only as four short blunt knobs, but one or more of them
are sometimes elongated. The eggs come from favored oocytes
that progressively swallow up their neighbors, lying in the space
around the manubrium.
When ripe the egg is very large and somewhat ameboid. (Allen
l900). mAfter fertilization a coeloblastula is formed. Gastrulation
has been described (Benoit '25) as a mixture of delamination and
multipolar proliferation. The embryos are developed up to the
actinula" stage within the gonophore. The actinula is to be con-
sidered as a precociously metamorphosing form, part planula and part
polyp.  
Open some female genophores and study the larvae thus liberated.
The younger ones are flattened, with blunt marginal processes. it
first these are not symmetrical in outline, but radial symmetry is
attained later. when the larva has reached the actinula stage it
has a mouth and tentacles, and a rounded aboral body that later be~
cmnes attached.
